article:
In American and Canadian football, 'instant replay' is a method of reviewing a
play using cameras at various angles to determine the accuracy of the initial
call of the officials. An instant replay can take place in the event of a close
or otherwise controversial call, either at the request of a team's head coach
(with limitations) or the officials themselves.

There are restrictions on what types of plays can be reviewed. In general, most
penalty calls or lack thereof cannot be reviewed, nor can a play that is
whistled dead by the officials before the play could come to its rightful end.
Examples of plays that cannot be reviewed â even if replays would show an
incorrect call was made â include a quarterback fumble recovered by the
defensive team that is ruled an incomplete pass and thus whistled dead, or a
player ruled downed or out of bounds when in fact he was not.

American and Canadian football leagues vary in their application and use of
instant replay review.
